Stay Informed: Stay well-informed about local air quality updates and be vigilant for any further deterioration in air quality that might impact your health.
Indoor Activities: Avoid all outdoor activities and limit exposure to outdoor air. Engage in indoor activities to reduce exposure to high levels of outdoor pollutants.
Air Purifiers: Use a high-quality air purifier with a HEPA filter in indoor spaces, focusing on areas where you spend the most time. This can help reduce indoor air pollution.
Ventilation: Ensure good ventilation in your living spaces. Use exhaust fans and open windows and doors when outdoor air quality improves to facilitate air circulation.
Use Masks: Consider using a mask, such as an N95 mask, when going outdoors, especially if you need to engage in activities that could expose you to higher levels of pollutants.
Stay Hydrated: Maintain proper hydration by drinking an adequate amount of water throughout the day. Staying hydrated is crucial for overall health, especially during periods of environmental stress.

Stay Informed: Stay closely informed about local air quality updates and adhere to any evacuation or safety guidelines provided by local authorities.
Indoor Activities: Avoid all outdoor activities and remain indoors as much as possible. Keep windows and doors tightly closed to minimize exposure to outdoor pollutants.
Air Purifiers: Use a high-efficiency air purifier with a HEPA filter in indoor spaces. Focus on creating a safe indoor environment, especially in areas where you spend the most time.
Ventilation: Minimize ventilation with outdoor air during periods of hazardous air quality. If possible, create a safe room with minimal entry points for outdoor air.
Use Masks: Wear a high-quality mask, such as an N95 mask, if you must go outdoors, and avoid prolonged exposure.
Stay Hydrated: Maintain proper hydration by drinking an adequate amount of water throughout the day. Staying hydrated is crucial for overall health and can help the body cope with environmental stress.

Stay Informed: Stay informed about local air quality forecasts and alerts, even when the AQI is low. This awareness can help you make informed decisions about outdoor activities.
Indoor Activities: Engage in indoor activities during periods when air quality is lower to minimize exposure to potential outdoor pollutants.

Stay Hydrated: Maintain proper hydration by drinking an adequate amount of water throughout the day. Staying hydrated is important for overall health, especially for individuals undergoing cancer treatment.

Stay Informed: Keep track of local air quality forecasts and alerts. Many weather websites and apps provide real-time air quality information.
Indoor Activities: On days with poor air quality, consider staying indoors as much as possible. Keep windows and doors closed to prevent outdoor pollutants from entering your home.
Air Purifiers: Consider using air purifiers with HEPA filters to help reduce indoor air pollutants.
Ventilation: Ensure good ventilation in your living spaces. Use exhaust fans and air circulation systems to improve indoor air quality.
Use Masks: In situations where outdoor exposure is necessary, consider wearing a mask designed to filter out particulate matter, especially if you have respiratory conditions.
Stay Hydrated: Drink plenty of water to help your body flush out toxins and stay hydrated.

Stay Informed: If conditions allow, consider relocating to an area with better air quality, such as a location with a lower AQI.
Indoor Activities: Remain indoors at all times and avoid any outdoor activities. Keep windows and doors tightly closed to prevent outdoor pollutants from entering indoor spaces.
Air Purifiers: Utilize high-efficiency particulate air (HEPA) filters in air purifiers to help reduce indoor air pollution.
Ventilation: Designate a room in the house as a safe room with additional air purifiers and minimal entry points for outdoor air.
Use Masks:
When necessary to go outdoors (e.g., for medical emergencies), wear high-quality masks, such as N95 masks, to provide maximum protection against particulate matter.
Monitor respiratory symptoms closely and seek immediate medical attention if there are signs of distress or if symptoms worsen significantly.
Stay Hydrated: Drink plenty of water to stay hydrated and support overall health.

Ventilation: Ensure good ventilation in your living spaces. Use exhaust fans and open windows and doors when outdoor air quality improves to facilitate air circulation.
Use Masks: Consider using a mask, such as an N95 mask, when going outdoors, especially if you need to engage in activities that could expose you to higher levels of pollutants.
Stay Hydrated: Maintain proper hydration by drinking an adequate amount of water throughout the day. Staying hydrated is crucial for overall health, especially during periods of environmental stress.

Stay Informed: If conditions allow, consider relocating to an area with better air quality, such as a location with a lower AQI.
Indoor Activities: Remain indoors at all times and avoid any outdoor activities. Keep windows and doors tightly closed to prevent outdoor pollutants from entering indoor spaces.
Air Purifiers: Utilize high-efficiency particulate air (HEPA) filters in air purifiers to help reduce indoor air pollution.
Ventilation: Designate a room in the house as a safe room with additional air purifiers and minimal entry points for outdoor air.
Use Masks:
When necessary to go outdoors (e.g., for medical emergencies), wear high-quality masks, such as N95 masks, to provide maximum protection against particulate matter.
Monitor respiratory symptoms closely and seek immediate medical attention if there are signs of distress or if symptoms worsen significantly.
Stay Hydrated: Drink plenty of water to stay hydrated and support overall health.

Stay Informed: Stay informed about local air quality forecasts and alerts, even when the AQI is low. This awareness can help you make informed decisions about outdoor activities.

Air Purifiers: Consider using an air purifier with a HEPA filter in indoor spaces to further improve air quality and reduce potential indoor pollutants.
Ventilation: Ensure good ventilation in your living spaces. Open windows and doors when the outdoor air quality is good to promote fresh air circulation.
Use Masks: While a mask may not be necessary when the AQI is 50 or lower, if there are specific concerns or if you are in a situation where air quality may be compromised, wearing a mask can offer an additional layer of protection.
Stay Hydrated: Maintain proper hydration by drinking an adequate amount of water throughout the day. Staying hydrated is important for overall health, especially for individuals undergoing cancer treatment.

Use Masks: Wear a high-quality mask, such as an N95 mask, if you must go outdoors, and avoid prolonged exposure.
Stay Hydrated: Maintain proper hydration by drinking an adequate amount of water throughout the day. Staying hydrated is crucial for overall health and can help the body cope with environmental stress.

Air Purifiers: Use a high-quality air purifier with a HEPA filter in indoor spaces, focusing on areas where you spend the most time. This can help reduce indoor air pollution.
Ventilation: Ensure good ventilation in your living spaces. Use exhaust fans and open windows and doors when outdoor air quality improves to facilitate air circulation.
Use Masks: Consider using a mask, such as an N95 mask, when going outdoors, especially if you need to engage in activities that could expose you to higher levels of pollutants.
Stay Hydrated: Maintain proper hydration by drinking an adequate amount of water throughout the day. Staying hydrated is crucial for overall health, especially during periods of environmental stress.

Stay Informed: Stay informed about local air quality forecasts and alerts, even when the AQI is low. This awareness can help you make informed decisions about outdoor activities.
Indoor Activities: Engage in indoor activities during periods when air quality is lower to minimize exposure to potential outdoor pollutants.

Use Masks: While a mask may not be necessary when the AQI is 50 or lower, if there are specific concerns or if you are in a situation where air quality may be compromised, wearing a mask can offer an additional layer of protection.
Stay Hydrated: Maintain proper hydration by drinking an adequate amount of water throughout the day. Staying hydrated is important for overall health, especially for individuals undergoing cancer treatment.

Stay Informed: Stay closely informed about local air quality updates and adhere to any evacuation or safety guidelines provided by local authorities.
Indoor Activities: Avoid all outdoor activities and remain indoors as much as possible. Keep windows and doors tightly closed to minimize exposure to outdoor pollutants.
Air Purifiers: Use a high-efficiency air purifier with a HEPA filter in indoor spaces. Focus on creating a safe indoor environment, especially in areas where you spend the most time.
Ventilation: Minimize ventilation with outdoor air during periods of hazardous air quality. If possible, create a safe room with minimal entry points for outdoor air.
Use Masks: Wear a high-quality mask, such as an N95 mask, if you must go outdoors, and avoid prolonged exposure.
Stay Hydrated: Maintain proper hydration by drinking an adequate amount of water throughout the day. Staying hydrated is crucial for overall health and can help the body cope with environmental stress.

Indoor Activities: Remain indoors at all times and avoid any outdoor activities. Keep windows and doors tightly closed to prevent outdoor pollutants from entering indoor spaces.
Air Purifiers: Utilize high-efficiency particulate air (HEPA) filters in air purifiers to help reduce indoor air pollution.
Ventilation: Designate a room in the house as a safe room with additional air purifiers and minimal entry points for outdoor air.
Use Masks:
When necessary to go outdoors (e.g., for medical emergencies), wear high-quality masks, such as N95 masks, to provide maximum protection against particulate matter.
Monitor respiratory symptoms closely and seek immediate medical attention if there are signs of distress or if symptoms worsen significantly.
Stay Hydrated: Drink plenty of water to stay hydrated and support overall health.

Ventilation: Ensure good ventilation in your living spaces. Use exhaust fans and air circulation systems to improve indoor air quality.
Use Masks: If it is necessary to go outdoors, wear high-quality masks, such as N95 masks, to provide better protection against particulate matter.
Stay Hydrated: Drink plenty of water to stay hydrated and support overall health.

Stay Informed: If conditions allow, consider relocating to an area with better air quality, such as a location with a lower AQI.
Indoor Activities: Remain indoors at all times and avoid any outdoor activities. Keep windows and doors tightly closed to prevent outdoor pollutants from entering indoor spaces.
Air Purifiers: Utilize high-efficiency particulate air (HEPA) filters in air purifiers to help reduce indoor air pollution.
Ventilation: Designate a room in the house as a safe room with additional air purifiers and minimal entry points for outdoor air.
Use Masks:
When necessary to go outdoors (e.g., for medical emergencies), wear high-quality masks, such as N95 masks, to provide maximum protection against particulate matter.
Monitor respiratory symptoms closely and seek immediate medical attention if there are signs of distress or if symptoms worsen significantly.
Stay Hydrated: Drink plenty of water to stay hydrated and support overall health.

Stay Informed: Stay informed about local air quality updates and forecasts, and be aware of any potential changes in the air quality that might affect your health.
Indoor Activities: Consider engaging in indoor activities during periods of moderate air quality to reduce exposure to outdoor pollutants.
Air Purifiers: Use an air purifier with a HEPA filter in indoor spaces, especially in areas where you spend a significant amount of time. This can help further improve indoor air quality.
Ventilation: Ensure good ventilation in your living spaces. Open windows and doors when the outdoor air quality is moderate to promote fresh air circulation.
Use Masks: Depending on your specific health condition and sensitivities, you may consider using a mask when going outdoors, especially if engaged in activities that could expose you to pollutants.
Stay Hydrated: Maintain proper hydration by drinking an adequate amount of water throughout the day. Staying hydrated is important for overall health and well-being.

Air Purifiers: Use air purifiers with HEPA filters indoors to help reduce indoor air pollutants.
Ventilation: Ensure good ventilation in your living spaces. Use exhaust fans and air circulation systems to improve indoor air quality.
Use Masks: Consider wearing masks designed to filter out particulate matter when going outdoors.
Stay Hydrated: Drink plenty of water to help flush out toxins and keep the respiratory system hydrated.

Stay Informed: Stay informed about local air quality updates and be vigilant for any further deterioration in air quality that might affect your health.
Indoor Activities: Avoid outdoor activities and minimize time spent outdoors. Engage in indoor activities to reduce exposure to outdoor pollutants.
Air Purifiers: Use a high-quality air purifier with a HEPA filter in indoor spaces, focusing on areas where you spend the most time. This can help reduce indoor air pollution.
Ventilation: Ensure good ventilation in your living spaces. Use exhaust fans and open windows and doors when outdoor air quality improves to facilitate air circulation.
Use Masks: Consider using a mask, such as an N95 mask, when going outdoors, especially if you need to engage in activities that could expose you to higher levels of pollutants.
Stay Hydrated: Maintain proper hydration by drinking an adequate amount of water throughout the day. Staying hydrated is crucial for overall health, especially during periods of environmental stress.
